page.title: 12R.A.F. North Luffenham
page.content: The R.A.F. station opened in 1941. Today it employs 1200 service people and 200 civilians. Runways are no longer used but the land is let to local farmers for grazing and silage crops. The camp is operational and deals with engineering, radar and cadet training. There are two areas of married quarters but many service people live in neighbouring villages after first receiving permission from the Commanding Officer. The camp has a NAAFI store, a bank and a doctor and dentist. There are clubs and societies run on the camp for service people and their families, some of which are open to members of the general public who belong to specific organizations such as members of the Scouting Movement. Christian worship is provided either on the camp or in the local parish church by 3 chaplains.
